page.title: 17Chickney, local history
page.content: Many place names are of Saxon origin. Broxted is from Brocces Heafod, Badger's Head or hill. Sibleys is derived from the Saxon name Sibba or Sibbi. Horham means a muddy dwelling. This historic house and gardens are open to the public several times a year in aid of charities. New Amberden Hall is an old house which was completely moved to a new site. Many people claim to have heard singing from the deserted church at Chickney. The dismantled railway goes right across the area from beyond Sibleys to Thaxted. Some of it forms a pleasant footpath where wild flowers and birds can be seen. Other parts are overgrown and neglected but still make a valuable preserve for plants, birds and animals. A short path on it leads to the reservoir at Sibleys Halt and Thaxted Station is now a coal depot.
